notes.description: Identify 6 different types of design systems.
bulletPoints: Alla Kholmatova - connected patterns, shared practices, coherently organized, serve a digital product
Andrew Couldwell - laying the foundations; order and consistency, protect brand, elevate UX, increase speed and efficiency in design and build
Invision/DesignBetter - reusable components, guided by clear standards, assemble for any app
Nathan Curtis - library of visual style, components, documentation as code and design for efficient and cohesive products
Jared Spool definition of design - design is the rendering of intent
Donella Meadows definition of systems - set of interconnected things that produce their own pattern of behavior over time
01 - brand identity/visual language (eg Nike, Absolut Vodka, National Parks)
02 - as tools (UI kits, Figma libraries, code-base frameworks)
03 - as a product (larger organizations with dedicated team with a backlog; Material Design, Lightening Design, Polaris)
04 - as a process (how products are built, user-centered flow, process and workflow)
05 - as a service (internal agency or consultancy to several feature teams)
06 - as a practice (any repetitive actions, scale)

640.resourceTitle: When hiring product designers, I look for ᴄᴀʀᴅɪᴏ

notes.description: CARDIO - context, assumptions, research, discoveries, iterations, outcome
bulletPoints: A design is only as good as its effectiveness at addressing some problem
Wicked problems — with no clear boundaries or inherent solution conditions
Tell me about a change you had to make to your initial design that ended up improving it.
Context - why did it matter? problem being solved from user perspective? Why business prioritize?
Assumptions - what was the initial hypothesis? Show thought process. Why believe right thing? Ownership of solution and direction?
Research - how was hypothesis tested? Feedback loops? Seek to disprove hypothesis, or merely validate assumptions?
Discoveries - useful conclusions from data? Effective synthesis, nuance, refinements? Conflict with business needs? Present and convince stakeholders?
Iteration - research is only as valuable as the actions that it drives. Compromises? Refinement of design
Outcome - impact of the decisions? What metrics/KPIs affected? Compare with initial objective.
30min of CARDIO everyday - regularly reflect on work with these 6 dimensions.
Able to link decisions to tangible business outcomes, so that value of work is clear?

notes.description: Recognise assumptions and prove they are correct
bulletPoints: Creating a new product - market fit discovery with fast, cheap experiments
Research existing products and competitors and recruit some beta users for v1
Explore the ‘problem’ space rigorously, before moving to solutions
Focus on benefits, not features
Target customer > underserved needs > product-market fit > value proposition > feature set > UX
Interviews and surveys, dummy landing pages and ad campaigns to test buying intent
1 - map out customer jobs, pains and gains
2 - assumption mapping quadrants; known / unknown / crucial / non-crucial - top right being highest risk
3 - test assumptions; customer interviews, expert interviews, search trends, shadowing, discussion forums, surveys, user test existing products
4 - Create multiple test cards for each hypothesis - hypothesis, test, metric, criteria
5 - document tests on riskiest assumptions in results cards - belief, observations, learnings, actions
6 - develop value propositon; gain creators, pain relievers, products and services
7 - business model canvas; desirability, feasibility, validity
8 - prototype testing; simple landing page, clickable prototype, low-code product, single feature MVP
8 - Design sprint; test beta with small amount of users
9 - define a product strategy and roadmap; rank hypothesis in priority, now, next, later
10 - OKRs to measure effectiveness
11 - mindset of experimentation; continuous discovery

445.resourceTitle: How to Choose Colors for Data Visualizations

notes.description: Color will highlight the story to be told
bulletPoints: Three major types of color palette: Qualitative; Sequential; Diverging
Qualitative: the variable is categorical. Categorical variables take on distinct labels without inherent ordering, like country, state, race, gender
Qualitative colors need to be distinct;  rule of thumb, limit to ten or fewer colors
Bundle smaller categories into 'other'
Adjust lightness and saturation for differences, but not too different as some colors will communicate greater importance
Sequential: variable is numeric or has ordered values; assigned in continuum, usually based on lightness and hue
Lower numbers are usually lighter, in light backgrounds. Use reverse for dark backgrounds, higher numbers lighter and brighter
Diverging: can span between 2 hues - warm to cool, with a meaningful central value like zero
Discrete vs continuous - clear blocks vs smooth gradient, former is clearer and used more
Avoid unnecessary color and be consistent across charts when same entity
Use color conventions like with sports teams or political parties
Use grey to reduce importance and create focus
Tools: Coblis Color blindness simulator; colorbrewer2.org; learnui.design color picker; Chroma.js; color-thief (inspiration from images); Viz Palette
